lbh15.lbe module

Module with liquid lead-bismuth-eutectic (LBE) class. LBE object can be initialized with the temperature or with one of the available properties (see LBE for the full list). It must be underlined that instantiation from properties depends on the specific correlation of the properties implemented in lbh15 package. In addition to the class attributes that are shown in this section, LBE class dynamically adds the properties implemented in lbh15.properties.lbe_properties module. For instance:

>>> from lbh15 import LBE
>>> liquid_lbe = LBE(T=668.15)
>>> liquid_lbe.k
13.058977206137499

Therefore the object comes with the following default properties:

  • \(T_{m0}\) lbe melting temperature:

    \(398.0 [K]\)

  • \(Q_{m0}\) lbe melting latent heat:

    \(38.6\cdot10^3 \Big[\frac{J}{kg}\Big]\)

  • \(T_{b0}\) lbe boiling temperature:

    \(1927 [K]\)

  • \(Q_{b0}\) lbe vaporisation heat:

    \(856.6\cdot10^3 \Big[\frac{J}{kg}\Big]\)

  • \(p_s\) lbe saturation vapour pressure \([Pa]\):

    \(p_s(T) = \displaystyle1.22\cdot10^{10}\cdot \exp{\Big(-22852/T\Big)}\)

  • \(\sigma\) lbe surface tension \(\Big[\frac{N}{m}\Big]\):

    \(\sigma(T) = \displaystyle\Big(448.5 - 0.0799{\cdot}T\Big)\cdot10^{-3}\)

  • \(\rho\) lbe density \(\Big[\frac{kg}{m^3}\Big]\):

    \(\rho(T) = \displaystyle11065 - 1.293{\cdot}T\)

  • \(\alpha\) lbe thermal expansion coefficient \(\Big[\frac{1}{K}\Big]\):

    \(\alpha(T) = \displaystyle\Big(8558 - T\Big)^{-1}\)

  • \(u_s\) speed of sound in lbe \(\Big[\frac{m}{s}\Big]\):

    \(u_s(T) = \displaystyle1855 - 0.212{\cdot}T\)

  • \(\beta_s\) lbe isentropic compressibility \(\Big[\frac{1}{Pa}\Big]\):

    \(\beta_s(T) = \displaystyle\frac{1}{\rho(T){\cdot}u_s(T)^2}\)

  • \(c_p\) lbe specific heat capacity \(\Big[\frac{J}{kg{\cdot}K}\Big]\):

    \(c_p(T) = \displaystyle164.8 - 3.94\cdot10^{-2}{\cdot}T + 1.25\cdot10^{-5}{\cdot}T^2 - 4.56\cdot10^{5}{\cdot}T^{-2}\)

  • \(h\) lbe specific enthalpy (as difference with respect to the melting point enthalpy) \(\Big[\frac{J}{kg{\cdot}K}\Big]\):

    \(h(T) = \displaystyle 164.8\cdot\Big(T - T_{m0}\Big) - 1.97\cdot10^{-2}\Big(T^2 - T_{m0}^2\Big) + 4.167\cdot10^{-6}\Big(T^3 - T_{m0}^3\Big)\)

    \(\qquad\qquad- 4.56\cdot10^5\Big(T^{-1} - T_{m0}^{-1}\Big)\)

  • \(\mu\) lbe dynamic viscosity \([Pa{\cdot}s]\):

    \(\mu(T) = \displaystyle4.94\cdot10^{-4}\cdot \exp{\Big(754.1/T\Bigg)}\)

  • \(r\) lbe electrical resistivity \([\Omega{\cdot}m]\):

    \(r(T) = \displaystyle\Big(90.9 + 0.048{\cdot}T\Big) \cdot10^{-8}\)

  • \(k\) lbe thermal conductivity \(\Big[\frac{W}{m{\cdot}K}\Big]\):

    \(k(T) = \displaystyle3.284 + 1.617\cdot10^{-2}{\cdot}T - 2.305\cdot10^{-6}{\cdot}T^2\)

  • \(Pr\) Prandtl number \([-]\):

    \(Pr = \displaystyle\frac{c_p\cdot\mu}{k}\)

where \(T\) is the lbe temperature in \([K]\).

Finally, the object dynamically adds useful methods to retrieve more information on specific thermophysical property which are named <property_name>_info. For instance:

>>> from lbh15 import LBE
>>> liquid_lbe = LBE(T=668.15)
>>> liquid_lbe.k_info()
k:
        Value: 13.0590 [W/(m*K)]
        Validity range: [398.00, 1100.00] K
        Long name: thermal conductivity
        Units: [W/(m*K)]
        Description:
                Liquid lbe thermal conductivity
class LBE(**kwargs)

Class to model liquid lead-bismuth eutectic properties at a given temperature

Parameters

**kwargs (dict) –

Dictionary that specifies the quantity from which the object shall be initialized. The default available ones are:

  • T (float) : temperature [K]

  • p_s (float) : saturation vapour pressure [Pa]

  • sigma (float) : surface tension [N/m]

  • rho (float) : density [Kg/m^3]

  • alpha (float) : thermal expansion coefficient [1/K]

  • u_s (float) : speed of sound [m/s]

  • beta_s (float) : isentropic compressibility [1/Pa]

  • cp (float) : specific heat capacity [J/(kg*K)]

  • h (float) : specific enthalpy (in respect to melting point) [J/kg]

  • mu (float) : dynamic viscosity [Pa*s]

  • r (float) : electrical resistivity [Ohm*m]

  • k (float) : thermal conductivity [W/(m*K)]

Examples

>>> liquid_lbe = LBE(T=600.0)
>>> liquid_lbe.mu  # [Pa*s]
0.001736052003181349
static T_at_cp_min()

Temperature in [K] corresponding to specific heat minimum

Return type

float

static cp_min()

Minimum value of cp correlation in [J/(kg*K)]

Return type

float

Type

float

vaporisation heat [J/kg]

Type

float

melting latent heat [J/kg]

Type

float

Type

classmethod correlations_available()

Dictionary of correlations available for each property

Return type

dict

classmethod correlations_to_use()

Returns the dictionary with the specific correlation to use for each specified property

Return type

dict

property p

pressure adopted for property calculation, i.e., atmospheric pressure

Type

float

classmethod properties_for_initialization()

List of available properties that can be used for initialization

Return type

list

classmethod roots_to_use()

Returns the dictionary with temperature roots to use for each specified property

Return type

dict

classmethod set_correlation_to_use(property_name, correlation_name)

Set specific correlation to use for property

Parameters

  • property_name (str) – Name of the property

  • correlation_name (str) – Name of the correlation

classmethod set_custom_properties_path(file_path)

Set absolute path of file where looking for custom properties

Parameters

file_path (str) – absolute path of file where custom properties are implemented

classmethod set_root_to_use(property_name, root_index)

Set which temperature root shall be used for initialization from property. Temperature roots are sorted in ascending order, i.e, T_i <= T_j with i < j. Used only if property correlation is not injective

Parameters

  • property_name (str) – Name of the property

  • root_index (int) – Index used to choose the temperature root
